title: Bottles Left Behind After Buying a House: What to Do
metaTitle: Found Wine in a New House? What to Do | Proof Cellars
metaDescription: Did you buy a house and find wine left behind? Learn how to assess the value, check condition, and sell the collection safely.
summary: How to assess condition, avoid scams, and submit photos safely when provenance is unknown.
tableOfContents: Identify if it is Trash or Treasure

sections.heading: Quick Answer
content: Finding a cellar in a new home is a common 'windfall' scenario. But without history, value depends entirely on condition.
list: Don't move the bottles yet (keep them stable).
Check if the cooling unit is actually working.
Verify ownership (ensure it conveyed with the house).
Take photos for a professional opinion.
Sell quickly if you don't plan to maintain the climate control.

sections.heading: Identify if it is Trash or Treasure
content: Previous owners often leave behind 'junk' they didn't want to move. But sometimes they leave gems.
list: Treasure Signs: Wooden crates, French labels (Bordeaux/Burgundy), vintage dates older than 2000.
Trash Signs: Screw caps (mostly), jugs, vinegar smell in the room, grocery store brands.

sections.heading: Condition Liability
content: Since you didn't buy the wine, you don't know if the AC was off for a summer. Buyers will be cautious.
list: Look for signs of seepage (sticky necks).
Push corks (are they protruding?).
We verify condition, but assume a 'risk discount' applies for unknown history.

sections.heading: Who Owns It?
content: Check your closing documents. Typically, personal property left after closing belongs to the buyer, but verify :
list: Was the wine specifically excluded in the contract?
Is there a post-occupancy agreement allowing them to retrieve items?
If clear, you have the right to sell.

sections.heading: Common Mistakes
list: Turning off the cellar AC to save electricity.
Moving bottles to the warm garage to 'clean up'.
Trying to drink valuable old wine without preparing it (decanting).

sections.heading: What to Do Next
list: Keep the room dark and cool.
Photograph the racks (don't unload everything yet).
Send us the photos for a 'triage' assessment.
We can organize a pickup if the value warrants it.

faqs.question: Is the wine still good?
faqs.answer: If the room feels cool (under 65Â°F), there is a good chance. If it feels like a normal room or hot, the wine may be cooked.

faqs.question: Can I sell it legally?
faqs.answer: If you own the property and the contents, you can sell to a licensed buyer like us.

faqs.question: What if I find whiskey?
faqs.answer: Whiskey is much more durable than wine. Even if stored warm, it is likely valuable and sellable.

faqs.question: Do you buy the racks?
faqs.answer: No, we only buy the liquid assets.

faqs.question: How do I know what it is worth?
faqs.answer: Submit photos. We give free valuations for collections.
